Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 10:14AM Padiddle wrote: I switched oncologists when I was dx stage IV.  I saw my first onc for the initial treatment and nine years of remission.  I've been seeing my stage IV onc for four years now.  He has shared a little bit of his personal life (small talk), and I have shared a little about me too.  It's probably a typical patient/doctor relationship but I know he will feel awkward at "the talk."  We had a pre-talk a couple months ago when I asked him about the long-term expectations.  You could tell he felt bad telling me that he could not cure me (which I already knew).  I know I do not want to be in panic mode for a miracle cure when I get the talk, but I don't know what my reaction will be.  Other patients have gotten "the talk" while I'm getting an infusion.  You can tell.  The atmosphere of the clinic changes.  You can see it on the faces of the nurses too.  It's gotta be tough for all.  I'm hoping the pre-talk took some of the edge off.  Jean
Posts.Title: It's gotta be tough Chickadee stagefree

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 11:22AM Padiddle wrote: I found it helpful to have a pre-talk with my onc.  He talked about QOL, the fact that my body may not be able to process all this chemo at some point, the possibility of organ failure.  He put no time-frame on anything.  It wasn't a discussion to scare me or discourage me in any way.  My husband was there too.  It wasn't the "there's nothing more we can do talk."  It was reviewing the facts and facing them.  All in all, it was helpful.  Jean

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 01:30PM Padiddle wrote: Hello:  My name is Jean.  I am 53.  Married 25 years with three grown children and one grandchild.  Was diagnosed in 2000 at 40 yrs old with stage IIb.  Had surgery, chemo, rads.  Nine years later, lump appeared above collar bone and was diagnosed with metastatic disease in bones, small spots in liver and lungs.  Ovaries removed, radiation to sternum, FEMARA and Zometa.  Progression, started Megace.  Progression started Taxol.  Progression and currently on Gemzar and Xgeva.  Had port placed on the right side last week as my veins were shot (hip, hip hooray!).  Stitches came out today.  Yesterday, had chemo.  Noticed a couple weeks ago my left chest wall was swelling.  Showed onc yesterday and he sent me for immediate CAT scan.  Waiting to hear results.  What the heck.  Did I mention I hate this disease too? Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 05:41AM - edited Mar 26, 2010 05:59AM by Padiddle Hi Brenda:  I did taxotere treatment nine years ago.  I looked back in my journal to see what I wrote about it.  I wrote that on the fourth day after treatment, I would get sore throat that included my mouth, sinus headaches, body aches and sore fingernails.  I seemed to feel better by the next round of chemo which was every three weeks.  I did write that I used Sudafed and Motrin to help with the sinus issues.  When I finished all the taxotere treatment, my fingernails and toenails fell off, but slowly grew back to normal.  My blood counts were a little slow in bouncing back after the last treatment, but eventually came back to normal.  It wasn't a picnic, but do-able.  I rested when I needed too.  I wish you well.  Jean I want to add that I had 4 rounds of AC before the taxotere and then radiation which gave me nine years of remission!

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 05:33AM Padiddle wrote: Zumbagirl:  I think it's so shocking that we need time to process all the information bit by bit.  I remember when I was first diagnosed in 2000, my surgeon's assistant came into the exam room to tell me the surgeon was concerned that I did not understand what she was telling me.  She asked me tell her what I thought the surgeon said to me.  Just recently, I wondered why so many girls new the grade of their cancers and I had no idea what grade mine was.  Why was that so important?  I looked on the metastatic pathology report from 2009 and couldn't find anywhere that gave a grade.  I'm happy you have finished the chemo part and you can start the radiation treatment.  Some gals like to count each one, some don't.  I didn't want to make it feel like it was dragging on, so I just counted week 1, week 2, etc., so there was less counting and it seemed like it went by faster.  The American Cancer Society has a very good website if you want to learn more detail about your diagnosis.  It's one of the only websites my onc recommends.  Hope you are feeling well as you recover from chemo.  For me, radiation was a little tiring but I got home and did an exercise routine after each one to help me with energy.  I also drank lots of water on my way to the radiation center.  I was working full-time at that point too.  Lots going on.  I stayed away from events from school as my children were in middle school at the time.  It kept me safe from all the colds and flus going on.  Watch for information overload, bit by bit learn about your particular stats.  Blessings.  Jean

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 03:25PM - edited Jan 17, 2014 03:31PM by Moderators Hi Rose:  Here is a discussion that was going on about skin mets (it's only two pages)   http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topic/81...  I had sternum radiation in 2009 and developed skin mets in 2011 near a mx scar.  I have never had radiation to the skin mets.  Progression other than the skin mets have had me in chemotherapy.  Some of the chemo has shrunk back some of the skin mets, but they have never completely disappeared.  I recently had new mets pop up in the peritoneum so I've just switched to Halaven and was curious as to whether or not Halaven would effect the skin mets.  Onc uses the skin mets as sort of a marker and does examine them once a month.  I don't know what radiation recall is so I can't contribute anything to that.  Sorry you are having to deal with the issue of skin mets.  I do hope your next scans are stable and the skin mets are coincidental.  I don't think they are dangerous but yes "blech."  Jean Edited by Mods to make link hot.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 08:12AM Padiddle wrote: Karen:  Sorry you got skin mets.  Mine don't cause worsening symptoms, but some types can ooze.  There are 3 or 4 different types of skin mets.  Although they are a type of progression, onc uses them as a tumor marker of sorts to see if they respond to the current treatment but isn't overly concerned about them.  It upset me a lot when they were first biopsied and confirmed, but in hindsight a skin met isn't like progression in a vital organ.  Those worry me more.  Steelrose:  The peritoneal mets I got have been a real pain for me and doc prescribed pain meds yesterday.  I've been resistant to taking narcotics since my stage IV dx, but gave in yesterday.  I've read about the constipating side effects of pain meds so the last thing I've got to do is to pick up Senokot to help with that.  I hope your pain can be managed.  Getting as comfortable as we can is so important.  I don't really know or understand much about the radiation recall.  I've had radiation at initial stage II diagnosis and then nine years later to the sternum when I was dx stage IV. Take care all.  Jean

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2013 11:07AM Padiddle wrote: A friend of mine decided to have a "celebration of life," before she died during her hospice time.  Her wish was to attend her own funeral.  Her family and friends helped her.  She spent the day at a Bill Cosby show and got to her funeral pretty tired out but so enjoyed the event.  It was a pig roast held at an old train depot in a quiet town nearby.  She had one of her favorite local bands play and she made it a point to visit with every person there.  She was quite tired and weak by that point, but it was important to her to do this and she made it a point to make it a big event for her, for her family, and for her friends.  When she did pass away, the family followed her wishes and gathered privately to spread her ashes in different places that she enjoyed going to.  I don't know whether or not these events are for the deceased or the living, but I do know that my friend "Diane," wanted it to be for her and did it her way.  Jean
